problems.problem_instructions: The museum team has drafted the welcome message for the grand opening, but it has accidental leading and trailing spaces. Given the raw message `raw_msg`, write a function `clean_message` that returns the message with no extra whitespace at the start or end.
problems.example_usage:
raw_msg = "   Welcome to the Grand Museum   "
print(clean_message(raw_msg))

raw_msg = "	  Exhibit A: Ancient Scripts  \n"
print(clean_message(raw_msg))

raw_msg = "NoExtraSpaces"
print(clean_message(raw_msg))
problems.example_output:
"Welcome to the Grand Museum"
"Exhibit A: Ancient Scripts"
"NoExtraSpaces"

problems.problem_instructions: After cleaning up the message, the curator needs to properly title-case each exhibit name. Given a string `title` where words are separated by spaces, write `title_case` to return the string with the first letter of each word capitalized and the rest lowercase.
problems.example_usage:
title = "ancient pottery COLLECTION"
print(title_case(title))

title = "the mystery of the lost scroll"
print(title_case(title))

title = "SINGLE"
print(title_case(title))
problems.example_output:
"Ancient Pottery Collection"
"The Mystery Of The Lost Scroll"
"Single"

problems.problem_instructions: The marketing team wrote a paragraph describing the new exhibit. Given the description string `desc`, write `count_words` to return the number of words in it (words are separated by one or more spaces).
problems.example_usage:
desc = "Explore the secrets hidden in ancient scripts"
print(count_words(desc))

desc = "   Leading and   multiple   spaces   "
print(count_words(desc))

desc = ""
print(count_words(desc))

problems.problem_instructions: The curator wants to highlight the most impressive word in each exhibit description. Given `desc`, write `longest_word` to return the longest word. If there is a tie, return the first occurring one.
problems.example_usage:
desc = "Guardians oversee every artifact carefully"
print(longest_word(desc))

desc = "small big BIGGEST tiny"
print(longest_word(desc))

desc = ""
print(longest_word(desc))

problems.problem_instructions: An ancient tablet bears an inscription. Given the raw string `inscription`, write `is_palindrome` to return `True` if the inscription reads the same backward and forward when ignoring non-letter characters and case, otherwise `False`.
problems.example_usage:
inscription = "A man, a plan, a canal: Panama"
print(is_palindrome(inscription))

inscription = "No lemon, no melon"
print(is_palindrome(inscription))

inscription = "Hello, World!"
print(is_palindrome(inscription))

problems.problem_instructions: Each artifact has a code string. The registrar needs the most common character in the code. Given `code`, write `most_frequent_char` to return the character that appears most often. If multiple tie, return any one.
problems.example_usage:
code = "AABCCCCCBB"
print(most_frequent_char(code))

code = "abcabcabc"
print(most_frequent_char(code))

code = ""
print(most_frequent_char(code))

problems.problem_instructions: The security team embedded a secret keyword in the exhibit description. Given `desc` and `keyword`, write `contains_keyword` to return `True` if `keyword` appears as a substring in `desc`, otherwise `False`.
problems.example_usage:
desc = "The hidden keyword is demeter"
keyword = "demeter"
print(contains_keyword(desc, keyword))

desc = "Guardians watch over the vault"
keyword = "vault"
print(contains_keyword(desc, keyword))

desc = "No keyword here"
keyword = "none"
print(contains_keyword(desc, keyword))

problems.problem_instructions: Over time, some exhibit labels developed repeated letters. Given a label string `label`, write `dedupe_label` to return a new string with only the first occurrence of each character (in original order).
problems.example_usage:
label = "balloon"
print(dedupe_label(label))

label = "MISSISSIPPI"
print(dedupe_label(label))

label = ""
print(dedupe_label(label))

problems.problem_instructions: Two artifacts have labels that might be anagrams. Given strings `a` and `b`, write `are_anagrams` to return `True` if one is an anagram of the other (ignoring case and non-letter characters), otherwise `False`.
problems.example_usage:
a = "Listen"
b = "Silent"
print(are_anagrams(a, b))

a = "Triangle"
b = "Integral"
print(are_anagrams(a, b))

a = "Apple"
b = "Pap ley"
print(are_anagrams(a, b))

problems.problem_instructions: The curator wants to send a secret message using a Caesar cipher. Given `msg` and integer `shift`, write `caesar_cipher` to return the encoded message by shifting each letter forward by `shift` (wrapping within the alphabet), preserving case and leaving non-letters unchanged.
problems.example_usage:
msg = "Attack at Dawn!"
shift = 3
print(caesar_cipher(msg, shift))

msg = "Hello, World!"
shift = 5
print(caesar_cipher(msg, shift))

msg = "Zoo Keeper"
shift = 2
print(caesar_cipher(msg, shift))

problems.problem_instructions: During an archaeological survey, a restorer uncovered a mirrored inscription. Given the string `mirrored_text`, write `reverse_text` to return the text in correct order.
problems.example_usage:
mirrored_text = "!dlroW ,olleH"
print(reverse_text(mirrored_text))

mirrored_text = "12345"
print(reverse_text(mirrored_text))

mirrored_text = "racecar"
print(reverse_text(mirrored_text))

problems.problem_instructions: After orientation, the restorer must count vowel annotations. Given the string `page_text`, write `count_vowels` to return the number of vowels (`a`, `e`, `i`, `o`, `u`, case-insensitive).
problems.example_usage:
page_text = "Restoration in progress"
print(count_vowels(page_text))

page_text = "AEIOUaeiou"
print(count_vowels(page_text))

page_text = "Rhythms"
print(count_vowels(page_text))

problems.problem_instructions: Each folio label mixes letters and digits. Given `label`, write `extract_page_number` to pull out all digits and return them as an integer (or `0` if none).
problems.example_usage:
label = "FolioA42B"
print(extract_page_number(label))

label = "Page007"
print(extract_page_number(label))

label = "SectionX"
print(extract_page_number(label))

problems.problem_instructions: Scanned text often has irregular spacing. Given `raw_text`, write `normalize_spaces` to replace any sequence of whitespace with a single space and trim leading/trailing spaces.
problems.example_usage:
raw_text = "  The   ancient   scroll  "
print(normalize_spaces(raw_text))

raw_text = "Line1\n\tLine2  Line3"
print(normalize_spaces(raw_text))

raw_text = "NoExtraSpaces"
print(normalize_spaces(raw_text))

problems.problem_instructions: Restored entries use dates as `DD-MM-YYYY`. Given `date_str`, write `reformat_date` to return it as `YYYY/MM/DD`.
problems.example_usage:
date_str = "05-07-1920"
print(reformat_date(date_str))

date_str = "1-1-2000"
print(reformat_date(date_str))

date_str = ""  
print(reformat_date(date_str))

problems.problem_instructions: For the digital archive, filenames are in snake_case. Given `file_name`, write `snake_to_camel` to convert it to camelCase.
problems.example_usage:
file_name = "ancient_scroll_image"
print(snake_to_camel(file_name))

file_name = "page_001_overview"
print(snake_to_camel(file_name))

file_name = "single"
print(snake_to_camel(file_name))

problems.problem_instructions: The transcriber noted that `f` was used in place of `s`. Given `script_text`, write `replace_archaic_f` to replace every `f`/`F` with `s`/`S` respectively.
problems.example_usage:
script_text = "The fauthor of the fcript"
print(replace_archaic_f(script_text))

script_text = "FOO Bar"
print(replace_archaic_f(script_text))

script_text = "Nothing to change"
print(replace_archaic_f(script_text))
problems.example_output:
"The sauthor of the script"
"SOO Bar"
"Nothing to change"

problems.problem_instructions: The restoration report uses semicolons instead of periods. Given `summary`, write `split_summary` to split by semicolons and return a list of trimmed sentences.
problems.example_usage:
summary = "Page cleaned; Ink restored; Ready for display"
print(split_summary(summary))

summary = ";Leading semicolon; Ends with semicolon;"
print(split_summary(summary))

summary = "Single sentence"
print(split_summary(summary))
problems.example_output:
["Page cleaned", "Ink restored", "Ready for display"]
["Leading semicolon", "Ends with semicolon"]
["Single sentence"]

problems.problem_instructions: Valid manuscript IDs contain only letters, digits, and hyphens. Given `manuscript_id`, write `is_valid_id` to return `True` if valid, otherwise `False`.
problems.example_usage:
manuscript_id = "MN-1234A"
print(is_valid_id(manuscript_id))

manuscript_id = "ID_007"
print(is_valid_id(manuscript_id))

manuscript_id = "ARCHIVE-2025"
print(is_valid_id(manuscript_id))

problems.problem_instructions: To standardize labels, page numbers must be zero-padded to width 4. Given integer `page_num`, write `pad_page_number` to return it as a string padded with leading zeros.
problems.example_usage:
page_num = 5
print(pad_page_number(page_num))

page_num = 123
print(pad_page_number(page_num))

page_num = 10000
print(pad_page_number(page_num))

problems.problem_instructions: During the capsule audit, the crew finds entries prefixed with a status. Given the string `entry`, write `has_warning_prefix` to return `True` if `entry` starts with `"WARNING:"`, otherwise `False`.
problems.example_usage:
entry = "WARNING: Oxygen levels critical"
print(has_warning_prefix(entry))

entry = "STATUS: All systems nominal"
print(has_warning_prefix(entry))

entry = ""
print(has_warning_prefix(entry))

problems.problem_instructions: Each message in the capsule ends with the senderâ€™s signature after a dash. Given `entry`, write `extract_signature` to return the substring after the last dash, or `""` if no dash is found.
problems.example_usage:
entry = "Log complete -Captain Silva"
print(extract_signature(entry))

entry = "Final note -Eli"
print(extract_signature(entry))

entry = "Unmarked message"
print(extract_signature(entry))

problems.problem_instructions: Crew commands are logged as `COMMAND: parameter`. Given `log_line`, write `parse_parameter` to return the substring after the colon and space, or `""` if the format is invalid.
problems.example_usage:
log_line = "SET_THRUST: 75%"
print(parse_parameter(log_line))

log_line = "DEPLOY_LANDING_GEAR: engaged"
print(parse_parameter(log_line))

log_line = "INVALIDENTRY"
print(parse_parameter(log_line))

problems.problem_instructions: The historian searches for key terms in the transcript. Given `record` and `keyword`, write `first_occurrence` to return the index of the first occurrence of `keyword` in `record`, or `-1` if not found.
problems.example_usage:
record = "Log entry at sector Z23"
keyword = "sector"
print(first_occurrence(record, keyword))

record = "No match here"
keyword = "error"
print(first_occurrence(record, keyword))

record = "Repeat repeat"
keyword = "repeat"
print(first_occurrence(record, keyword))

problems.problem_instructions: To mark the final mention, the archivist needs the last position of a term. Given `log_text` and `term`, write `last_occurrence` to return the index of the last occurrence of `term`, or `-1` if absent.
problems.example_usage:
log_text = "ABABA"
term = "BA"
print(last_occurrence(log_text, term))

log_text = "No repeat here"
term = "repeat"
print(last_occurrence(log_text, term))

log_text = "Edge edge EDGE"
term = "EDGE"
print(last_occurrence(log_text, term))

problems.problem_instructions: For digital encoding, each character maps to its ASCII code. Given `text`, write `to_ascii_codes` to return a list of ASCII integers for every character in order.
problems.example_usage:
text = "A!"
print(to_ascii_codes(text))

text = "Hi"
print(to_ascii_codes(text))

text = ""
print(to_ascii_codes(text))

problems.problem_instructions: To reverse the encoding, convert a list of codes back to text. Given a list `codes`, write `from_ascii_codes` to return the decoded string.
problems.example_usage:
codes = [65, 66, 67]
print(from_ascii_codes(codes))

codes = [32, 33]
print(from_ascii_codes(codes))

codes = []
print(from_ascii_codes(codes))

problems.problem_instructions: To compress repeated symbols, the engineer uses run-length encoding. Given `signal`, write `run_length_encode` to return a string where each character is followed by its count of consecutive repeats.
problems.example_usage:
signal = "AAABB"
print(run_length_encode(signal))

signal = "XYZ"
print(run_length_encode(signal))

signal = ""
print(run_length_encode(signal))

problems.problem_instructions: The AI classifier distinguishes code formats. Given `code`, write `code_type` to return `"alpha"` if it contains only letters, `"digit"` if only digits, or `"alphanumeric"` if both letters and digits.
problems.example_usage:
code = "ARCHIVE"
print(code_type(code))

code = "12345"
print(code_type(code))

code = "A1B2C3"
print(code_type(code))

problems.problem_instructions: For legacy normalization, the archivist swaps letter cases. Given `note`, write `swap_case` to return a new string where each uppercase letter becomes lowercase and vice versa.
problems.example_usage:
note = "Hello"
print(swap_case(note))

note = "WORLD"
print(swap_case(note))

note = "123AbC"
print(swap_case(note))
